executive_summary: The Piece Goods, Notions and Other Apparel Wholesaling industry will decline over the five years to 2023. A combination of rising import penetration, intense price competition and vertical integration has caused industry revenue to contract at a CAGR of 2.6% to $15.2 billion over the five years to 2023...

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 resulted in a dramatic downturn in the economy, disrupting global supply chains and undercutting industry demand, ultimately exacerbating its decline.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: LOW-COST IMPORTS CONTINUE TO UNDERCUT WHOLESALERS
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The inundation of low-cost imports into the domestic apparel market has continued to reduce the role of domestic wholesalers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: THE POSITION OF WHOLESALERS HAS DETERIORATED
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The continued offshoring of large-scale apparel manufacturing has pushed out wholesalers unable to cater to niche markets in an industry where profitability is low.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: IMPORT PENETRATION WILL CONTINUE TO DETERIORATE THE POSITION OF WHOLESALERS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Low-cost apparel imports will continue to substitute domestically produced apparel and associated items.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: CUSTOMERS WILL LOOK TO E-COMMERCE OPTIONS TO CUT OUT INDUSTRY OPERATORS
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Consumer shopping habits have trended toward digital channels, accelerated by changes that kept individuals at home during the pandemic.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: STRONG MINING DEMAND WILL BE A BRIGHT SPOT
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: While mining demand will come down from previous highs, it will remain substantial because of high commodity prices.

industry_definition: Operators in this industry wholesale piece goods, fabrics, yarns, thread and other notions and hair accessories.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level: low - steady

key_trends: The pandemic created unprecedented volatility for wholesalers.
Import penetration into apparel manufacturing has cut out domestic wholesalers.
The industry remains heavily dependent on unskilled labor.
Wholesalers are subject to a range of product standards.
Synthetic fabrics have benefited from their versatility.
Wholesalers position themselves near major trading hubs.
Population is a key determinant of the geographic distribution of wholesalers.
Because of high fragmentation, the industry is highly competitive.
Wholesale bypass is a primary threat to the industry.
Profit for industry wholesalers has declined.
Purchases are the largest cost for industry wholesalers.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Downstream wholesalers are the largest market for the industry.
Mining companies purchase synthetic fabric for use in industrial operations.
Other buyers of piece goods and notions include government, individual consumers, restaurants and businesses.

market_segmentation.segment: Businesses for use as an input

products_and_services.product_or_service: Piece Goods and Other Miscellaneous Knit Fabrics
products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes woolen and worsted fabrics, woven and knit piece goods.
The synthetic fabrics of this segment have a wide range of uses.
The cotton fabric in this segment is primarily for clothing.
Notions are small articles attached to a larger piece of apparel.

tier_1_suppliers: Employment & Recruiting Agencies in the US
Human Resources & Benefits Administration in the US
tier_1_buyers: Leather Good & Luggage Manufacturing in the US
tier_2_buyers: Women's, Girls' and Infants' Apparel Manufacturing in the US
Costume & Team Uniform Manufacturing in the US
Household Furniture Manufacturing in the US
Men's & Boys' Apparel Wholesaling in the US
Women's & Children's Apparel Wholesaling in the US
Cut & Sew Apparel Contractors in the US
Men's & Boys' Apparel Manufacturing in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Lower Cost of Piece Goods Promotes Growth
demand_determinants.determinant_description: As the prices of other industry products have risen, manufacturers have switched to piece goods and miscellaneous fabrics.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Synthetic Fabrics Benefit From Their Versatility
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The versatility of synthetic fiber has increased its popularity.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Cotton Fabrics Remain a Staple Product
demand_determinants.determinant_description: The rising price of cotton has undermined demand for cotton-based fabric.

business_locations.location_description: The largest number of industry piece goods wholesalers are located here.
Many wholesalers locate here for inexpensive shipping costs.
The Southeast region holds the highest percentage of the US population.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The industry is subject to The Sherman Antitrust Act and other regulations.
In 2010, the EPA created guidelines limiting the use of older vehicles.
Product standards include communication, design, and performance standards.
Various levels of regulation have been implemented due to COVID-19.

basis_points.basis_description: The industry is highly competitive with many small operators.

concentration_points.concentration_title: A lack of large players enables smaller companies to thrive
concentration_points.concentration_description: No individual wholesalers account for more than 5.0% of total revenue.

concentration_points.concentration_title: WHOLESALERS ARE BEING BYPASSED BY MANUFACTURERS
concentration_points.concentration_description: Large retailers are sourcing directly from manufacturers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Includes piece goods, yarns, thread, and other apparel goods.
Wages account for 10.8% of revenue in 2023.
Profit accounts for 4.1% of revenue in 2023.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry relies on manual labor for its operations.
The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Demand from apparel manufacturing has suffered from intense competition.

volatility_points.volatility_title: COVID-19 HAS CAUSED MASSIVE REVENUE SWINGS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Industry revenue depends on downstream demand.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Lower Cost of Piece Goods Promotes Growth
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Manufacturers have switched to piece goods and miscellaneous fabrics.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Synthetic Fabrics Benefit From Their Versatility
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Synthetic fabrics have a wide range of uses.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Cotton Fabrics Remain a Staple Product
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Cotton fabric is primarily for clothing but demand has been undermined.
Notions are small articles attached to apparel.

FAQs.question: Are your sales heavily dependent on any one market, major customer or other isolated revenue stream?
FAQs.answer: A significant share of industry revenue is generated by downstream demand from manufacturing and mining industries.

FAQs.question: How does your company maintain a competitive edge in such a crowded industry?
FAQs.answer: Price competition and market coverage are essential for companies to gain a competitive edge.

FAQs.question: How does the size of your company affect its profitability and growth potential?
FAQs.answer: Generally, larger companies will be able to generate favorable contracts with suppliers.

FAQs.question: Does your company have a viable strategy in place to grow sales, and if so, what is that strategy?
FAQs.answer: Companies that stock and promote new products have a better chance of increasing their sales.

FAQs.question: Does your company currently have an e-commerce platform for volume sales? If not, do you have plans to create one?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers can potentially benefit from having an e-commerce platform.

FAQs.question: Does your company use RFID to optimize inventory management and improve efficiency?
FAQs.answer: RFID technology helps companies manage inventory levels by reducing costs.

FAQs.question: How does your company monitor potential changes to the regulatory environment?
FAQs.answer: Some companies within the industries are members of trade associations.

FAQs.question: Does your company benefit (either directly or indirectly) from any government legislation?
FAQs.answer: Imports are subject to US customs laws.

FAQs.question: How does volatility in the value of the dollar affect demand and profit?
FAQs.answer: The value of the dollar influences import penetration into the domestic apparel manufacturing industry.

FAQs.question: How has input price volatility affected your purchase costs and selling prices?
FAQs.answer: The price of cotton and synthetic fibers fluctuates based on supply.

FAQs.question: How often does your company introduce new products to its line? What does your company spend on new products annually?
FAQs.answer: Wholesalers that stock and promote new products are more likely to survive.

FAQs.question: Does your company have strong relationships with its suppliers?
FAQs.answer: Diverse supplier links enable operators to provide a variety of product types.

FAQs.question: How large is your company's product range, and are margins relatively low?
FAQs.answer: Most successful operators sell a large range of products with relatively small margins.

FAQs.question: How has the inundation of imports affected your company?
FAQs.answer: Domestic manufacturers are forced to close or move production overseas.

FAQs.question: How dependent is your revenue on downstream apparel manufacturers?
FAQs.answer: Weakening downstream demand from this market segment has fueled the industry's decline.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the trade-weighted index?
FAQs.answer: An appreciating dollar weakens domestic manufacturing industries.
